summary: In Mansour v. Sukumal, the High Court of the Western Judicial Division in Ghana considered whether a new lease existed after the expiration of an initial seven-year lease. Although the parties had executed a written lease with a proposed rent, they subsequently agreed to refer the rent determination to the Rent Assessment Committee and abide by its decision. The Committee initially set the rent at �1,207 10s. per annum, but this was later reduced to �600 per annum by the District Magistrate. The landlord sought possession under section 11(1)(e)(i) of the Rent Control Ordinance, claiming the tenants were statutory tenants. The court held that a complete agreement existed due to the method of rent determination, constituting a valid lease. Thus, the tenants were not statutory tenants, and the landlord could not rely on the Ordinance to recover possession. Judgment was entered for the defendants.
legalKeywords: id certum est quod certum reddi potest

jurisdiction.court: High Court, Western Judicial Division, Divisional Court

citations: Rent Control Ordinance, c. 2 of 1952, s. 11(1)(e)(i)
Rent Control Ordinance, c. 2 of 1952, s. 16(1)
rationaleHighlights: Agreement on method of rent determination constitutes complete agreement (id certum est quod certum reddi potest)
Execution of lease document and submission to Rent Assessment Committee evidenced mutual intent
Payment of rent based on Committee's assessment confirmed tenancy under new terms
Novation of original lease established new contractual relationship
Defendants not statutory tenants under s.16(1) due to existence of lease
Plaintiff failed to prove defendants were statutory tenants
Landlord not entitled to possession under s.11(1)(e)(i) without statutory tenancy
confidenceNotes: The decision is clearly articulated with reference to statutory provisions and legal principles. The reasoning is consistent with contract and property law doctrines, particularly regarding novation and completeness of agreement. High confidence in accuracy.
